content.heading: A Survey of Fiber Bragg Grating Sensors for Physical Parameter Monitoring in Engineering
1 Abstract
content.content: Fiber Bragg grating (FBG) sensors have become a pivotal technology in the field of physical parameter monitoring, offering high sensitivity, compactness, and immunity to electromagnetic interference. These sensors are widely used in engineering systems for real-time monitoring and control, particularly in applications involving strain, temperature, and force sensing. This survey paper provides a comprehensive overview of the current state of research on FBG sensors, with a focus on shape and force sensing techniques. It examines data-driven approaches, including adaptive learning, uncertainty quantification, and deep learning, as well as model-independent and hybrid sensing methods. The paper also explores advanced techniques such as distributed shape sensing, force and stiffness estimation, and the integration of FBG sensors into smart and embedded systems. The main contributions of this work include a structured review of methodologies, a critical evaluation of their advantages and limitations, and an identification of research gaps and future directions. By consolidating recent advancements, this survey highlights the potential of FBG sensors to enhance the accuracy, robustness, and adaptability of intelligent systems in complex environments. This work serves as a valuable reference for researchers and practitioners aiming to develop next-generation sensing technologies for engineering and biomedical applications.

content.heading: 2 Introduction
content.content:
The development of fiber Bragg grating (FBG) sensors has revolutionized the field of physical parameter monitoring in engineering, offering a versatile and reliable means of measuring strain, temperature, and other critical variables [1]. These sensors have gained widespread adoption due to their high sensitivity, compact size, and immunity to electromagnetic interference, making them ideal for deployment in complex and dynamic environments. The integration of FBG technology into various engineering systems has enabled real-time monitoring and feedback control, enhancing the performance and safety of structures, robots, and medical devices. As the demand for intelligent and adaptive systems continues to grow, the role of FBG sensors in providing accurate and robust data becomes increasingly significant [2]. This has led to a surge in research focused on improving sensor design, signal processing, and integration with advanced control algorithms to address the challenges of real-world applications.

This survey paper provides a comprehensive overview of the current state of research on fiber Bragg grating (FBG) sensors for physical parameter monitoring in engineering, with a particular focus on shape and force sensing [1]. It explores the latest advancements in data-driven sensing and learning, including adaptive learning for shape estimation, uncertainty quantification in deep neural networks, and the application of supervised learning and Siamese networks for edge-FBG shape sensing. The paper also examines model-independent and hybrid sensing approaches, such as the use of deep learning for real-time control and online adaptation in robotic systems. Additionally, it covers distributed shape sensing techniques, force and stiffness sensing, and the integration of FBG sensors into smart and embedded systems [3]. The goal of this survey is to provide a structured and critical analysis of the methodologies, challenges, and opportunities in the field, offering insights for future research and development.

The paper begins by introducing the fundamental principles of FBG sensing and its applications in engineering systems, followed by a detailed discussion of data-driven approaches that leverage machine learning and deep learning for enhanced performance. It then explores the integration of FBG sensors with real-time control systems, emphasizing the importance of online adaptation and uncertainty quantification in dynamic environments. The discussion extends to advanced sensing techniques, such as distributed shape sensing and force estimation, which are critical for applications requiring high spatial resolution and accuracy. The paper also highlights the use of FBG sensors in specialized configurations, such as ice monitoring and biological mimicry, as well as their application in extreme environments [2]. Finally, it addresses the integration of FBG sensors into smart and embedded systems, including the development of FBG-based smart insoles and the use of dual comb spectroscopy for precision strain and torsion sensing [4]. These sections collectively provide a comprehensive understanding of the current state of research and its implications for future engineering applications.

This survey paper makes several key contributions to the field of FBG-based physical parameter monitoring [5]. It offers a structured and up-to-date review of the methodologies and techniques used in shape and force sensing, providing a valuable reference for researchers and practitioners. The paper critically evaluates the advantages and limitations of data-driven approaches, such as adaptive learning and uncertainty quantification, and highlights their potential for improving the accuracy and robustness of FBG-based systems. Additionally, it identifies gaps in current research and outlines future directions for further exploration. By consolidating the findings from a wide range of studies, the survey serves as a foundation for developing more advanced and intelligent FBG sensing systems that can meet the demands of complex engineering applications [2]. The insights provided in this paper aim to guide future research and promote the adoption of FBG sensors in a variety of fields, from robotics and medical devices to structural health monitoring and environmental sensing [5].

content.heading: 3.1.1 Adaptive Learning for Shape Estimation
content.content:
Adaptive learning for shape estimation has emerged as a critical area in robotics and medical systems, driven by the need for real-time, accurate, and robust shape reconstruction. Traditional model-based methods often rely on simplifying assumptions and precise sensor data, which can be limiting in complex or dynamic environments. In contrast, adaptive learning approaches leverage data-driven models to capture nonlinear deformation behaviors and reduce dependency on explicit mechanical models. By integrating sensor data such as FBG measurements with learning-based frameworks, these methods enable more flexible and accurate shape prediction, particularly in scenarios where sensor fidelity is variable or uncertain. This shift towards data-driven modeling is particularly beneficial in applications involving continuum manipulators, where precise shape estimation is essential for safe and effective operation [6].

The integration of deep learning techniques into shape estimation has significantly advanced the field, particularly through the use of sim-to-real frameworks that generate large-scale training datasets. These frameworks utilize digital twins in simulation environments to create diverse and realistic scenarios, which are then transferred to real-world systems. This approach not only addresses the challenge of data scarcity but also enhances the generalization capability of learning models. Additionally, adaptive learning methods incorporate mechanisms for online parameter adjustment and uncertainty quantification, allowing the system to compensate for modeling errors and environmental disturbances. Such capabilities are crucial for applications like minimally invasive surgery, where the ability to adapt to unforeseen conditions can greatly improve safety and performance.

Recent advancements in adaptive learning for shape estimation have also focused on improving the scalability and robustness of sensor-based systems. Techniques such as machine learning-based calibration and uncertainty-aware prediction have been introduced to enhance the reliability of shape estimation under varying operational conditions. These methods reduce the need for manual tuning and improve compatibility across different sensor types and deployment scenarios. By combining sensor data with adaptive learning models, researchers have demonstrated significant improvements in contact prediction accuracy and real-time shape reconstruction. As the field continues to evolve, the integration of adaptive learning with advanced sensing technologies is expected to further enhance the capabilities of flexible robotic systems in complex and dynamic environments.

content.heading: 3.1.2 Uncertainty Quantification in Deep Neural Networks
content.content:
Uncertainty quantification in deep neural networks (DNNs) has emerged as a critical area of research, particularly in safety-critical applications such as robotics and medical systems. Traditional DNNs often lack the ability to express confidence in their predictions, which can lead to unreliable decision-making in uncertain environments. To address this, various techniques have been developed to estimate both aleatoric and epistemic uncertainties. Aleatoric uncertainty captures inherent noise in the data, while epistemic uncertainty reflects model uncertainty due to limited or noisy training data. These methods are essential for applications where reliable predictions and robustness to unseen data are paramount, such as in real-time control or autonomous systems.

Recent advancements in uncertainty quantification include Bayesian neural networks (BNNs), Monte Carlo Dropout, and ensemble methods, which provide probabilistic outputs and quantify model confidence. These approaches enable DNNs to not only make predictions but also assess the reliability of those predictions. For instance, Monte Carlo Dropout introduces stochasticity during inference to approximate Bayesian posterior distributions, allowing for uncertainty estimation without significant computational overhead. Such techniques are particularly valuable in scenarios where model misspecification or data scarcity is a concern, as they provide a more nuanced understanding of prediction reliability compared to deterministic models.

In the context of robotic systems, uncertainty quantification plays a pivotal role in enhancing safety and adaptability. By incorporating uncertainty estimates into decision-making processes, robots can better handle unpredictable environments and avoid erroneous actions. This is especially relevant in applications such as surgical robotics, where precise and reliable predictions are crucial. The integration of uncertainty-aware DNNs into control frameworks allows for adaptive compensation of modeling errors and disturbances, leading to improved performance and robustness. As the complexity of robotic systems increases, the ability to quantify and manage uncertainty becomes an indispensable component of modern machine learning approaches.

content.heading: 3.2.1 Supervised Learning for Edge-FBG Shape Sensing
content.content:
Supervised learning has emerged as a powerful approach for enhancing the accuracy and robustness of shape sensing in edge-FBG systems. By leveraging labeled datasets that pair sensor outputs with ground-truth shape configurations, these models can learn complex mappings between strain distributions and spatial deformations. This approach is particularly beneficial in scenarios where traditional analytical models struggle due to nonlinearities or environmental uncertainties. Recent studies have demonstrated that supervised learning frameworks, such as deep neural networks, can effectively capture the intricate relationships between edge-FBG signals and the physical shape of flexible structures, enabling real-time and high-resolution shape estimation [3]. The integration of such models with edge-FBG sensors offers a promising alternative to conventional methods that rely on simplified assumptions about strain distribution [7].

The application of supervised learning in edge-FBG shape sensing typically involves training models on datasets generated from controlled experiments or simulations. These datasets are often constructed by subjecting the sensor to known deformations and recording the corresponding spectral responses. Feature extraction and preprocessing steps are critical to ensure the model can effectively learn from the data. Techniques such as convolutional neural networks (CNNs) or recurrent neural networks (RNNs) have been employed to process temporal or spatial sensor data, while transformer-based architectures have shown potential in capturing long-range dependencies in signal sequences. The resulting models are then validated on unseen data to evaluate their generalization capability, ensuring reliable performance in real-world applications.

Despite the advantages of supervised learning, challenges remain in achieving consistent accuracy across varying environmental conditions and sensor configurations. Factors such as signal noise, sensor drift, and mechanical wear can degrade model performance, necessitating robust training strategies and regular retraining. Additionally, the need for large, high-quality labeled datasets can be a barrier to deployment in resource-constrained settings. However, ongoing research into data augmentation, transfer learning, and hybrid modeling approaches is addressing these limitations, further advancing the viability of supervised learning for edge-FBG shape sensing in practical applications.

content.heading: 3.2.2 Siamese Networks for Feature Discrimination
content.content:
Siamese networks have emerged as a powerful architecture for feature discrimination tasks, particularly in scenarios where the comparison of input pairs is critical. These networks consist of two or more identical subnetworks that share weights and process input pairs in parallel, enabling the model to learn a similarity metric between the inputs. In the context of robotic sensing and contact detection, Siamese networks are employed to distinguish between different states or conditions based on sensory data. By training the network to recognize subtle differences in feature representations, such as those derived from whisker-object interactions or fiber Bragg grating (FBG) signals, the model can effectively classify events like collisions or environmental contacts. This approach is particularly advantageous in situations where labeled data is scarce, as it leverages the structure of the input data to learn discriminative features without explicit supervision.

The application of Siamese networks in this domain involves careful design of the feature extraction module, which is typically a deep neural network tailored to the specific sensory modality. For instance, in the case of whisker contact tracking, the network may process time-series data from tactile sensors, while for FBG-based systems, it may analyze spectral signatures. The shared architecture of the Siamese network ensures that the same feature extractor is applied consistently to both inputs, promoting invariance to variations in the input data. This is crucial for maintaining robustness in real-world scenarios where environmental conditions and sensor noise can significantly affect the signal. Furthermore, the use of contrastive loss functions during training allows the network to optimize the distance between feature embeddings, thereby enhancing the model's ability to differentiate between similar but distinct input patterns.

In the context of robotic shape estimation and contact detection, Siamese networks offer a flexible and scalable solution for feature discrimination. By leveraging the learned similarity metric, these networks can be integrated into real-time systems for applications such as collision avoidance, object recognition, and environmental mapping. The ability to generalize across different sensor configurations and operating conditions makes Siamese networks a valuable tool in data-driven approaches to robotic perception. Their effectiveness in capturing complex, nonlinear relationships between inputs and outputs further underscores their relevance in modern machine learning applications within robotics and sensor systems.

content.heading: 3.3.1 Learning-Based Shape Flow Prediction
content.content:
Learning-based shape flow prediction has emerged as a critical component in enhancing the accuracy and adaptability of shape estimation in flexible robotic systems. This approach leverages machine learning models to predict the dynamic evolution of a device's shape over time, often using sensor data as input. By modeling the temporal dependencies in sensor signals, such as those from fiber Bragg grating (FBG) sensors, these methods can infer the movement and deformation of flexible structures in real time [1]. This is particularly beneficial in applications where the shape of the device changes rapidly, such as in medical robotics or continuum manipulators, where precise and timely predictions are essential for safe and effective operation.

Recent advancements in this area have focused on integrating deep learning architectures, such as transformer-decoders, to process historical sensor data and predict future contact points or shape configurations. These models are trained on datasets that include a variety of object interactions, allowing them to generalize across different scenarios. Additionally, the use of Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) for calibrating real-world sensor signals to simulated environments has further improved the reliability of these predictions. By combining these techniques, learning-based models can achieve high accuracy in shape flow prediction, even in the presence of complex deformations and dynamic interactions with the environment.

The integration of learning-based methods into shape flow prediction also addresses limitations of traditional mechanical models, which often rely on simplified assumptions that may not hold in real-world conditions. These data-driven approaches can adapt to varying operational scenarios and sensor characteristics, making them more robust and scalable. As a result, they enable more accurate and reliable shape estimation, which is crucial for applications requiring precise control and interaction with complex environments. This shift towards learning-based solutions represents a significant step forward in the development of intelligent and adaptive flexible robotic systems.

content.heading: 3.3.2 Online Adaptation in Robotic Systems
content.content:
Online adaptation in robotic systems is a critical capability that enables robots to dynamically adjust their behavior in response to changing environmental conditions or internal uncertainties. This is particularly important for mobile and continuum robots, which often operate in unstructured settings where traditional proprioceptive data may be unreliable due to drift or sensor noise [8]. Recent advancements have shifted towards data-driven approaches, such as deep learning, to enhance adaptability without relying on precise kinematic models. These methods leverage large-scale datasets generated through sim-to-real frameworks, allowing robots to learn and refine their perception and control strategies in real-time. By integrating sensor data from diverse modalities, such as fiber Bragg grating (FBG) sensing or monocular vision, online adaptation strategies can effectively compensate for modeling errors and external disturbances, ensuring robust performance in complex tasks.

The integration of machine learning (ML) techniques into online adaptation has significantly improved the accuracy and scalability of robotic systems. For instance, ML-based calibration methods, such as regression models trained across multiple sensor channels, offer a data-driven alternative to traditional analytical models, reducing the need for manual tuning and enhancing adaptability to non-ideal conditions. Similarly, uncertainty-aware approaches, such as those employing Monte Carlo Dropout, enable robots to not only predict their state but also quantify the confidence in their predictions, which is crucial for safe and reliable operation. These methods are particularly beneficial in applications like medical robotics, where precise control and real-time adjustments are essential to avoid damage to sensitive structures. By continuously updating their internal models and compensating for uncertainties, robotic systems can achieve greater autonomy and resilience in dynamic environments.

Online adaptation also plays a pivotal role in enabling real-time control and shape estimation for continuum manipulators, which are inherently non-linear and challenging to model [6]. Techniques such as neural network-based adaptive control and learning-based shape flow predictors allow these robots to update their kinematic models and servo-control their configurations without prior knowledge [6]. This is especially valuable in minimally invasive surgery, where accurate and reliable motion control is necessary for safe navigation within confined anatomical spaces [1]. The ability to adapt in real-time not only improves the precision of robotic interventions but also enhances their flexibility and responsiveness. As research continues to advance, the development of robust and scalable online adaptation strategies will be essential for expanding the capabilities of robotic systems in a wide range of applications.

content.heading: 4.1.1 OFDR-Based Shape Sensing for Soft Manipulators
content.content:
Optical Frequency Domain Reflectometry (OFDR)-based shape sensing has emerged as a promising technique for monitoring the configuration of soft manipulators in robotic systems, particularly in the context of minimally invasive and natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgeries. Unlike traditional fiber Bragg grating (FBG)-based methods, which require complex fabrication and precise alignment, OFDR leverages standard optical fibers and offers a more straightforward implementation. This approach enables high-resolution strain and curvature measurements along the length of a soft manipulator, facilitating real-time shape reconstruction without relying on kinematic models [9]. The use of OFDR-based sensors is particularly advantageous in environments where electromagnetic interference is a concern, as optical fibers are immune to such disturbances. This makes OFDR a suitable candidate for integration into flexible surgical instruments that operate in sensitive biomedical settings.

OFDR-based shape sensing works by analyzing the backscattered light from an optical fiber to infer local strain variations, which are then used to reconstruct the three-dimensional shape of the manipulator. The technique allows for continuous monitoring of the entire length of the robot, providing detailed information about its configuration in real time. This is crucial for applications where precise control and feedback are required, such as in delicate surgical procedures. Additionally, OFDR's ability to detect small curvature changes with high sensitivity makes it well-suited for applications involving complex, tortuous paths. The method also supports the integration of multiple sensing points along a single fiber, enhancing spatial resolution and enabling more accurate shape estimation. These features make OFDR-based shape sensing a compelling alternative to conventional sensor arrangements in soft robotic systems.

Despite its advantages, OFDR-based shape sensing still faces challenges in terms of signal processing complexity and the need for robust calibration procedures. The accuracy of shape reconstruction depends on the quality of the strain data and the effectiveness of the algorithms used to interpret it. Furthermore, the performance of OFDR in dynamic or highly deformable environments requires further investigation to ensure reliability under varying conditions. Ongoing research aims to optimize sensor layouts, improve signal-to-noise ratios, and develop more efficient algorithms for real-time shape estimation. As the demand for advanced soft manipulators in medical robotics continues to grow, refining OFDR-based techniques will be essential for achieving the precision and adaptability required in complex surgical tasks.

content.heading: 4.1.2 FBG-Embedded Instrument Monitoring
content.content:
FBG-embedded instrument monitoring has emerged as a critical technique for enhancing the precision and reliability of flexible medical robots, particularly in environments with large deflections and curvatures, such as flexible ureteroscopes and colonoscopes. Fiber Bragg grating (FBG) sensors offer advantages such as small size, biocompatibility, and immunity to electromagnetic interference, making them well-suited for integration into medical devices [10]. These sensors can measure strain and curvature along the length of a flexible instrument, enabling accurate shape tracking and force estimation. By embedding FBG sensors within the structure of the instrument, real-time monitoring of its deformation and interaction with the surrounding tissue becomes possible, which is essential for safe and effective robotic-assisted procedures [11].

Several methods have been developed to leverage FBG sensors for force and shape estimation in continuum robots [12]. For instance, curvature-based approaches use FBG measurements to calculate forces via constitutive laws, achieving mean errors of around 9.8% for force and 3.6% for location. Shape-based methods, such as those using Fourier transformation or distributed force profiles, offer additional insights into force distribution and location by analyzing the "peaks" in the sensor data. Moreover, advanced signal processing techniques like FastICA have been employed to decouple signals from multiple FBG sensors, improving the accuracy of force and shape reconstruction. These approaches have been applied in various medical applications, including force control in surgical instruments and slip prediction in robotic fingertips.

Recent advancements have focused on enhancing the sensitivity and accuracy of FBG-based monitoring through innovative sensor designs and configurations [2]. Ultra-short FBG sensors, for example, have been integrated into soft robotic fingers to enable static-dynamic force sensing, while novel structures like dual FBG arrays and protective tubes have improved repeatability and robustness [13]. Additionally, the use of multi-core FBGs and distributed FBG sensors, combined with advanced signal processing, has enabled 3D shape sensing with higher spatial resolution [14]. These developments underscore the growing importance of FBG-embedded monitoring in enabling precise, real-time feedback for flexible medical robots, ultimately contributing to safer and more effective clinical outcomes.

content.heading: 4.2.1 FBG-Based Stiffness Estimation
content.content:
FBG-based stiffness estimation has emerged as a promising technique for assessing mechanical properties in both robotic and biomedical applications. This method leverages the strain sensitivity of fiber Bragg grating (FBG) sensors to infer stiffness by analyzing the deformation of flexible structures under external loads [14]. The core principle involves correlating the wavelength shifts of FBG sensors with the mechanical strain induced by applied forces, which can then be used to estimate the stiffness of the surrounding medium or structure. This approach is particularly advantageous in environments where direct contact or invasive measurements are impractical, such as in minimally invasive surgery or soft robotic systems. The integration of FBG sensors into flexible manipulators enables real-time monitoring of stiffness changes, enhancing the precision and adaptability of robotic systems in dynamic and unstructured settings.

The development of FBG-based stiffness estimation methods has focused on improving accuracy and efficiency through advanced modeling and signal processing techniques. One key challenge is the accurate mapping of strain measurements to stiffness values, which requires a robust mechanical model that accounts for the complex interactions between the sensor, the structure, and the external forces. Recent studies have introduced simplified models that reduce computational complexity while maintaining high estimation accuracy. These models often incorporate curvature-based approaches, where the deformation of the structure is analyzed to infer stiffness properties. Additionally, optimization algorithms such as least squares are employed to refine the estimation process, ensuring reliable results even in the presence of noise or non-uniform loading conditions. These advancements have enabled the application of FBG-based stiffness estimation in a wide range of scenarios, from tissue characterization to structural health monitoring [11].

Experimental validation plays a critical role in demonstrating the effectiveness of FBG-based stiffness estimation techniques. Studies have tested these methods on various configurations, including single, double, and multiple force applications, to evaluate their performance under different conditions. The results consistently show that FBG-based systems can provide accurate and repeatable stiffness measurements, making them suitable for real-world applications. Furthermore, the integration of FBG sensors into compact and flexible designs has expanded their usability in confined or complex environments [2]. As research continues to refine these methods, the potential for FBG-based stiffness estimation to enhance robotic perception and medical diagnostics becomes increasingly evident, paving the way for more intelligent and responsive systems in the future.

content.heading: 4.2.2 Force Perception via FBG Layout and Decoupling
content.content:
The section on force perception via FBG layout and decoupling explores the design and implementation of fiber Bragg grating (FBG)-based sensors for accurate force estimation in flexible robotic systems [13]. The layout of FBG sensors plays a critical role in determining the sensitivity and accuracy of force detection, as the placement and orientation of the gratings influence the measurement of strain and curvature [15]. By strategically positioning FBG pairs on perpendicular surfaces of a robotic component, such as a prong or gripper, the system can capture multi-axis force information. This approach enables the detection of both the magnitude and direction of applied forces, which is essential for tasks requiring precise control and interaction with delicate environments. The design of the FBG layout must also consider the mechanical behavior of the host structure to ensure reliable signal acquisition.

Decoupling sensor signals is a crucial step in achieving accurate force perception, as multiple physical phenomena—such as bending, stretching, and torsion—can simultaneously affect the FBG measurements. A simplified model for curvature computation and force estimation is derived to address this challenge, allowing for faster and more efficient processing of sensor data. This model accounts for the relationship between axial strain and curvature, enabling the separation of force-induced strain from other mechanical effects. Experimental validation on single, double, and triple force cases demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed method in accurately estimating force magnitude and location. The results highlight the importance of signal decoupling in improving the reliability of FBG-based force sensing in complex robotic systems.

The integration of FBG sensors within flexible robotic structures presents unique challenges, particularly in maintaining high sensitivity while minimizing interference from unwanted mechanical deformations [9]. Traditional FBG-based sensors often suffer from limitations such as poor decoupling of bending and force effects, leading to reduced accuracy [5]. To overcome these issues, novel designs have been proposed, including the suspension of the FBG fiber within a chamber to allow direct interaction with the applied force. This configuration enhances the sensitivity and robustness of the sensor, making it suitable for applications in surgical robotics and other safety-critical environments. The development of advanced signal processing techniques further supports the decoupling process, ensuring that the measured data reflects the true force conditions. These innovations contribute to the broader goal of achieving precise and reliable force perception in flexible robotic systems.

content.heading: 4.3.1 Simultaneous Shape and Force Estimation
content.content:
Simultaneous shape and force estimation in flexible robotic systems is a critical area of research, particularly in applications such as minimally invasive surgery and complex manipulation tasks [15]. This section addresses the challenges of estimating both the geometric configuration and the external forces acting on a flexible robot, emphasizing the need for accurate and real-time feedback. Traditional approaches often rely on curvature measurements to infer force, but the interplay between bending and force introduces significant complexities. Researchers have explored various methods, including shape-based algorithms and distributed force estimation, to enhance accuracy and robustness in unstructured environments. These methods aim to provide reliable information for both teleoperation and autonomous control, ensuring safe and effective interaction with the environment.

Recent advancements in fiber Bragg grating (FBG) technology have enabled more precise and compact solutions for simultaneous shape and force estimation [1]. FBG sensors offer advantages such as small size, biocompatibility, and immunity to electromagnetic interference, making them suitable for medical and industrial applications [4]. However, challenges remain in decoupling the effects of bending and force, particularly in multi-degree-of-freedom systems. To address this, researchers have developed simplified models for fast curvature computation and force estimation, validated through experimental testing under various loading conditions [12]. These models aim to improve the accuracy of force localization and magnitude estimation, which is crucial for applications requiring high precision and safety.

The integration of advanced signal processing techniques, such as FastICA for sensor signal decorrelation, has further enhanced the performance of force estimation systems. These methods allow for the recovery of real forces exerted on robotic components, reducing errors in axial force estimation. Additionally, the use of multi-core fiber (MCF) and shape-sensing algorithms has shown promise in enabling temperature-invariant and real-time shape reconstruction. Despite these advancements, ongoing research is needed to address limitations such as sensor placement, sensitivity, and robustness to environmental disturbances. Future work should focus on optimizing sensor designs and algorithms to achieve more reliable and efficient simultaneous shape and force estimation in complex robotic systems.

content.heading: 4.3.2 Kalman Filter Integration for Dynamic Systems
content.content:
Kalman filter integration for dynamic systems has emerged as a critical technique for improving the accuracy and robustness of state estimation in real-time applications. By recursively predicting and updating system states based on noisy measurements, Kalman filters provide an optimal solution for systems with linear or nonlinear dynamics. In the context of dynamic systems, particularly those involving soft robotics and flexible structures, the Kalman filter is often adapted to handle nonlinearity through variants such as the Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) and the Unscented Kalman Filter (UKF). These methods enable accurate estimation of parameters like curvature, force, and position, which are essential for control and feedback in complex environments. The integration of Kalman filters with sensor data, such as fiber Bragg grating (FBG) measurements, has demonstrated significant improvements in estimation accuracy and system responsiveness.

The application of Kalman filters in dynamic systems often involves the fusion of multiple sensor modalities to enhance reliability and reduce uncertainty. For instance, in systems where FBG sensors are used to measure curvature, Kalman filters can be employed to compensate for measurement noise and model inaccuracies. This approach is particularly beneficial in environments where sensor readings are affected by external disturbances, such as temperature variations or mechanical vibrations. By incorporating prior knowledge of system dynamics and measurement characteristics, Kalman filters can effectively mitigate errors and provide more stable estimates. Additionally, the use of adaptive Kalman filters allows for real-time parameter adjustments, making them suitable for systems with time-varying behavior and uncertain dynamics.

Recent advancements in Kalman filter integration have focused on optimizing computational efficiency while maintaining high estimation accuracy. Techniques such as reduced-order modeling and parallel processing have been explored to enable real-time implementation in resource-constrained platforms. Furthermore, the combination of Kalman filters with machine learning algorithms has shown promise in improving adaptability and generalization across different operating conditions. These developments underscore the growing importance of Kalman filter-based methods in dynamic systems, particularly in applications requiring precise and reliable state estimation, such as robotic manipulation, medical devices, and autonomous systems.

content.heading: 5.1.1 CL-FBG Sensor for Ice Monitoring
content.content:
The CL-FBG sensor represents a specialized advancement in fiber Bragg grating (FBG) technology tailored for ice monitoring applications [10]. This sensor is designed to measure plane principal strain across the cross-section of a transmission line (TL), enabling the detection of bending, ice accretion weight, and freeze-thaw processes [16]. By incorporating six sets of temperature-strain sensing units, the CL-FBG sensor offers a comprehensive approach to monitoring the mechanical and thermal effects of ice accumulation [16]. Its ability to provide high-precision measurements makes it particularly suitable for environments where traditional sensors may struggle with accuracy or reliability due to harsh conditions. The sensor's design leverages the inherent advantages of FBGs, such as immunity to electromagnetic interference and compact size, which are critical for long-term deployment on TL structures.

One of the key challenges in ice monitoring is the accurate differentiation between strain and torsion effects, which can be confounded in conventional FBG setups [16]. The CL-FBG sensor addresses this by utilizing a circular configuration that enhances the detection of multi-directional deformations. This configuration allows for the simultaneous measurement of axial and transverse strain, which is essential for capturing the complex mechanical behavior of TL under ice loading. Additionally, the sensor's design facilitates the integration of intelligent algorithms, which can improve the accuracy and real-time response of ice monitoring systems. These algorithms help in distinguishing between various types of deformations and provide more reliable data for predictive maintenance and structural health monitoring.

The application of CL-FBG sensors in ice monitoring has shown promising results in both laboratory and field settings. Their ability to detect subtle changes in strain and temperature makes them effective in identifying early signs of ice accretion and assessing the structural integrity of TL. Furthermore, the integration of microclimate data such as temperature, humidity, and wind speed enhances the predictive capabilities of these sensors, allowing for more informed decision-making. As the demand for reliable and efficient ice monitoring solutions increases, the CL-FBG sensor offers a robust and scalable option that can be adapted to various environmental conditions and structural configurations.

content.heading: 5.1.2 DEA and FBG Integration for Biological Mimicry
content.content:
The integration of dielectric elastomer actuators (DEA) with fiber Bragg grating (FBG) sensors has emerged as a promising approach for achieving biological mimicry in soft robotic and adaptive systems [9]. This combination leverages the high sensitivity and spatial resolution of FBG sensors to monitor the deformation and strain of DEA, enabling precise feedback control. The non-intrusive nature of FBG allows for real-time monitoring without interfering with the actuation mechanism, making it suitable for applications requiring high flexibility and adaptability. The robustness of FBG against electromagnetic interference further enhances the reliability of the system in complex environments, aligning with the requirements of bio-inspired designs that emulate natural movement and response.

FBG sensors are particularly advantageous in capturing multi-dimensional strain and torsion data from DEAs, which is critical for mimicking the complex kinematics of biological systems [17]. By embedding multiple FBGs within the DEA structure, spatially distributed strain measurements can be obtained, providing a comprehensive understanding of the actuator's deformation behavior. This capability is essential for replicating the nuanced motions observed in living organisms, such as muscle contractions or joint movements. Additionally, the low bandwidth requirements of FBG systems make them compatible with compact and energy-efficient control architectures, which is crucial for the development of autonomous and portable bio-mimetic devices.

The synergy between DEA and FBG also facilitates the development of adaptive systems capable of responding to environmental stimuli in a manner similar to biological tissues. The ability to detect minute changes in strain and temperature allows for real-time adjustments, enhancing the responsiveness and efficiency of the actuation. This integration has been explored in various applications, including soft robotics, wearable devices, and biomedical prosthetics, where the goal is to achieve natural and intuitive interaction with the environment. The continued refinement of this technology holds significant potential for advancing the field of bio-mimetic engineering.

content.heading: 5.2.1 High-Field Magnetostriction Measurement
content.content:
High-field magnetostriction measurement is a critical technique for investigating the magnetic properties of materials under extreme conditions. This method involves applying a strong magnetic field and measuring the resulting dimensional changes in the material, which are directly related to its magnetization and spin interactions. The measurement process typically employs strain gauges or optical techniques to detect minute deformations, often in the range of micrometers or less. In the context of quantum magnets, high-field magnetostriction provides valuable insights into the interplay between spin correlations and mechanical strain, as the strain can be expressed as a function of the spin operators [18]. This approach is particularly useful in the megagauss regime, where traditional magnetization measurements may be limited by experimental constraints.

The experimental setup for high-field magnetostriction measurements often includes a cryogenic environment to control temperature and a high magnetic field generator capable of producing fields exceeding several Tesla. The sample is subjected to varying magnetic fields while the resulting strain is recorded using precision sensors. This technique is especially relevant for materials with complex magnetic ordering, where the magnetostriction effect can reveal details about the underlying magnetic structure. The sensitivity of the measurement is influenced by factors such as the sample size, material properties, and the accuracy of the strain detection system. These considerations are essential for ensuring reliable and reproducible results in high-field studies.

In addition to its fundamental scientific value, high-field magnetostriction has practical applications in the development of advanced magnetic materials and devices. The ability to measure strain under extreme magnetic conditions allows researchers to optimize material performance for use in high-field environments, such as in superconducting magnets or magnetic sensors. The integration of high-precision measurement techniques, such as fiber Bragg grating (FBG) sensors, can further enhance the accuracy and reliability of these studies [1]. By combining magnetostriction measurements with other characterization methods, researchers can gain a more comprehensive understanding of material behavior under extreme conditions.

content.heading: 5.2.2 Granular Matter Velocity Probing
content.content:
The section on granular matter velocity probing explores the application of fiber Bragg grating (FBG) sensors to measure the dynamic behavior of granular systems [19]. These sensors offer high spatial and temporal resolution, making them suitable for capturing the velocity distribution of particles in complex flow environments. By leveraging the strain and torsion sensitivity of FBG, researchers have demonstrated the ability to monitor particle motion with high precision. The technique involves analyzing the frequency shifts in the FBG spectrum, which are directly related to the mechanical deformations induced by particle interactions. This approach enables the extraction of velocity data without the need for direct optical access, which is particularly beneficial for opaque granular systems.

Experimental validation of the FBG-based velocity probing technique has been conducted using controlled granular flows at low volume fractions. The results show a strong correlation between the measured frequency shifts and the actual particle velocities, confirming the reliability of the method. Single-particle collision experiments have further refined the understanding of how FBG sensors respond to varying impact conditions, such as initial velocity and contact angle. These studies highlight the potential of FBG sensors to provide detailed insights into granular dynamics, including velocity fluctuations and energy dissipation mechanisms [19]. The ability to capture such data in real time enhances the applicability of FBG in both fundamental research and industrial monitoring.

The integration of FBG sensors into granular velocity probing presents a promising avenue for advancing the study of complex particulate systems [19]. However, challenges remain in optimizing the sensor configuration to balance time resolution with the number of particles that can be effectively monitored. Future work will focus on improving the spatial density of FBG arrays and enhancing signal processing algorithms to extract more detailed velocity information. The demonstrated capabilities of FBG in this context suggest that they could become a key tool for investigating granular flows in both laboratory and real-world settings.

content.heading: 5.3.1 FBG-Based Smart Insole for Biomechanics
content.content:
FBG-based smart insoles have emerged as a promising tool for biomechanical monitoring, offering high precision and reliability in capturing plantar pressure and gait-related data [4]. These insoles integrate Fiber Bragg Grating (FBG) sensors, which are capable of detecting strain and torsion simultaneously, enabling detailed analysis of foot mechanics. The FBG sensors are embedded within the insole structure, allowing for real-time data acquisition and transmission via wireless interfaces [2]. This technology is particularly beneficial for patients with foot complications, as it provides continuous and accurate monitoring of gait patterns, pressure distribution, and foot temperature, facilitating early detection of potential issues.

The design and implementation of FBG-based smart insoles involve careful sensor placement and characterization to ensure optimal performance. Studies have demonstrated the use of multiple FBG sensors strategically positioned to capture biomechanical parameters across different regions of the foot. These sensors are typically interrogated using optical methods, and their responses are analyzed to derive meaningful biomechanical insights. The integration of cloud-based data pipelines further enhances the utility of these insoles, enabling remote monitoring and data analysis. This approach not only supports clinical applications but also contributes to the development of personalized treatment strategies for patients with various foot-related conditions.

FBG-based smart insoles offer advantages over traditional sensing technologies, including immunity to electromagnetic interference and the ability to operate in harsh environments [4]. Their high sensitivity and durability make them suitable for long-term use in both clinical and ambulatory settings. Moreover, the capability to monitor multiple biomechanical parameters simultaneously enhances the comprehensiveness of the data collected. As research continues to advance, the application of FBG-based smart insoles in biomechanics is expected to expand, providing more accurate and actionable insights for patient care and rehabilitation [4].

content.heading: 5.3.2 Dual Comb Spectroscopy for Strain and Torsion
content.content:
Dual comb spectroscopy (DCS) has emerged as a powerful technique for precision measurements of mechanical deformations, particularly in the context of strain and torsion sensing. By leveraging two coherent optical frequency combs with distinct repetition rates, DCS enables high-resolution spectral analysis and temporal interrogation of fiber Bragg grating (FBG) sensors [20]. This approach allows for the simultaneous detection of strain and torsion through the measurement of wavelength shifts in the FBG reflection spectrum, which are directly related to the mechanical deformation of the host structure [20]. The high spectral resolution and broad bandwidth of DCS make it well-suited for applications requiring real-time monitoring of dynamic mechanical loads, such as in structural health monitoring and biomedical systems.

The integration of DCS with FBG-based sensing systems offers significant advantages in terms of sensitivity, accuracy, and operational simplicity. The use of optical combs facilitates the acquisition of high-speed data without the need for complex scanning mechanisms, enabling the detection of transient strain and torsion events. Additionally, the ability to perform multi-parameter sensing within a single measurement setup reduces system complexity and enhances reliability. Recent advancements in DCS have demonstrated its potential for high-frequency strain monitoring, with detection bandwidths reaching up to 100 MHz, making it applicable for applications such as magnetostriction measurements and dynamic load characterization. These capabilities position DCS as a promising tool for next-generation strain and torsion sensing systems.

Furthermore, the adaptability of DCS to various sensor configurations and environments expands its applicability across diverse fields. The technique can be integrated with different types of FBG sensors, including those optimized for temperature compensation and multi-axis strain sensing [4]. This flexibility is particularly beneficial in scenarios where simultaneous measurement of multiple mechanical parameters is required. As research continues to refine the performance and integration of DCS with FBG systems, its role in advanced strain and torsion sensing is expected to grow, offering new possibilities for real-time, high-precision mechanical monitoring in both industrial and scientific contexts [20].

content.heading: 6 Future Directions
content.content:
Despite significant advancements in the application of fiber Bragg grating (FBG) sensors for physical parameter monitoring, several limitations and gaps remain in the current research landscape. One major limitation is the lack of standardized methodologies for sensor calibration and data interpretation, which hinders the comparability and reproducibility of results across different studies. Additionally, the integration of FBG sensors with complex, real-time control systems still faces challenges in terms of computational efficiency and adaptability to dynamic environments. Many existing approaches rely on simplified models that may not fully capture the nonlinear and time-varying nature of sensor responses, especially in unstructured or extreme conditions. Furthermore, while data-driven techniques such as deep learning have shown promise, they often require large, high-quality datasets that may be difficult to obtain in practical applications. These limitations underscore the need for further research to improve the reliability, scalability, and generalizability of FBG-based sensing systems.

To address these challenges, future research should focus on developing more robust and adaptive sensor integration frameworks that can handle real-time data processing and uncertainty quantification. One promising direction is the refinement of hybrid sensing approaches that combine model-based and data-driven methods to enhance accuracy and reduce dependency on extensive training data. This could involve the development of physics-informed neural networks that incorporate domain-specific knowledge to improve model generalization and interpretability. Additionally, there is a need for more comprehensive studies on the long-term stability and reliability of FBG sensors in harsh or dynamic environments, including extreme temperatures, high humidity, and mechanical fatigue. Another important area of exploration is the optimization of sensor layout and placement strategies to maximize spatial resolution and minimize signal interference, particularly in multi-axis force and shape sensing applications. By addressing these issues, researchers can pave the way for more reliable and scalable FBG-based systems that can be deployed in a wide range of engineering and medical applications.

The proposed future work has the potential to significantly impact the fields of robotics, structural health monitoring, and biomedical engineering. By improving the accuracy and adaptability of FBG-based sensing systems, the development of more intelligent and responsive robotic systems becomes feasible, particularly in applications requiring precise control and real-time feedback. Enhanced sensor integration and data processing techniques could also lead to more effective monitoring of structural integrity in civil and aerospace systems, enabling early detection of damage and reducing maintenance costs. In the medical domain, advanced FBG-based sensors could improve the safety and precision of minimally invasive procedures, such as robotic surgery and rehabilitation devices. Overall, the continued advancement of FBG sensor technology, supported by innovative research in data-driven modeling, hybrid sensing, and real-time adaptation, will play a crucial role in shaping the next generation of smart, autonomous, and reliable sensing systems.

content.heading: 7 Conclusion
content.content:
This survey paper provides a comprehensive overview of the current state of research on fiber Bragg grating (FBG) sensors for physical parameter monitoring in engineering, with a particular focus on shape and force sensing. The review highlights the evolution of data-driven sensing and learning techniques, including adaptive learning for shape estimation, uncertainty quantification in deep neural networks, and the application of supervised learning and Siamese networks for edge-FBG shape sensing. It also covers model-independent and hybrid sensing approaches, such as the use of deep learning for real-time control and online adaptation in robotic systems, as well as distributed shape sensing techniques, force and stiffness sensing, and the integration of FBG sensors into smart and embedded systems. These advancements demonstrate the growing potential of FBG sensors in providing accurate, reliable, and robust data for a wide range of engineering applications, from robotics and medical devices to structural health monitoring and environmental sensing.

The significance of this survey lies in its structured and critical analysis of the methodologies, challenges, and opportunities in the field of FBG-based physical parameter monitoring. By consolidating findings from a broad range of studies, the paper offers a valuable reference for researchers and practitioners seeking to advance the design, implementation, and application of FBG sensors. The paper emphasizes the importance of data-driven approaches in overcoming the limitations of traditional model-based methods, particularly in dynamic and uncertain environments. It also underscores the role of uncertainty quantification and online adaptation in enhancing the reliability and performance of FBG-based systems. The insights presented in this work aim to guide future research and promote the adoption of FBG sensors in emerging fields, such as intelligent robotics, precision medicine, and smart infrastructure.

Looking ahead, the continued development of FBG-based sensing technologies will require interdisciplinary collaboration to address existing challenges, such as improving sensor robustness, optimizing signal processing algorithms, and expanding the scalability of data-driven models. Future research should also focus on integrating FBG sensors with emerging technologies, including artificial intelligence, edge computing, and quantum sensing, to unlock new capabilities in real-time monitoring and decision-making. As the demand for intelligent and adaptive systems grows, the role of FBG sensors in enabling precise and reliable data acquisition will become increasingly vital. This survey serves as a foundation for further exploration and innovation in the field, encouraging the development of more advanced and intelligent FBG sensing systems that can meet the evolving needs of complex engineering applications.
